HOPKINS QUINTET
OPEN HOME GAME
WITH NOREEN

Powerful Outfit

MARGOLIS, SIEGEL
Coaches Mallonee, Twardowicz Prime Eager Squad;

Tonight at 8.30 p. m. a fighting
Hopkins quintet opens the Maryland
Intercollegiate League against a
powerful Washington five. By 11.15
we should all be acquainted with the
outcome. Whether the local five triumphs or goes down to defeat, we
may be sure that a fast-cutting,
sharpshooting unit, will take the
floor for the Hopkins.
Jays Lost To Strong Team
Coaches Gard Mallonee and Utz
Twardowicz have labored for the
past few weeks with a meager veteran squad. Their efforts have not
been useless. Against an exceptionally strong Temple quintet Hopkins
went down to a heroic defeat, losing
in the final period by a 44-17 score.
The victors lead at half time by but
five points. This same Temple team
routed Purdue, co--holders of the title in the Big Ten Conference, after
this same team had held N. Y. II.,
one of the bulwarks of intercollegiate
basketball in the East, to a one point
victory. In the second game of the
current season, the varsity trimmed
a courageous alumni squad by the
score of 51-37. Coming from behind
after a slow start, the home team
soared into a commanding lead,
which it kept throughout. Its ability
to handle the ball was outstanding.
On Wednesday, Hopkins traveled to
West Point and lost to a veteran
Academy outfit. The score, 39-23.
Regulars To Start
Hopkins will probably open with
Captain George Margolis and Carl
Raisin at the guard positions. Herb
Siegel, veteran of two campaigns and
Emanuel "Ace" Zheutlin will hold
flown the forward berths with Norman Melvin at the all-important
center position. The offensive is
built around Captain Margolis and
"Hopping" Herb Siegel, high scorer
of the squad last year, "Hawk-eye"
Raisin, Zheutlin, and Melvin fit nicely in a scheme stressing fast cutting
and accurate passing. Zheutlin, posssessing a good left as well as right
hand shot, has been particularly encouraging during the past week.
Breaking into the line-up after languishing on the bench last season,
"Ace" seems ready to go. Those who
probably will see action are: Les

NAMED TRUSTEE
Dr. Lewis H. Weed, Baltimore, a
member of the faculty of the Johns
Hopkins Medical School, has been
elected to the board of trustees of
the Carnegie Institute of Washington, which has recently authorized
an appropriation of $572,000 for scientific work in 1936.

Gartner To Speak Here
Dr. Ross A. Gartner, of the
chemistry faculty of the University of Minnesota and as resident
lecturer at Cornell University during 1935, will deliver the third in
the Dohme lecture series this afternoon at four o'clock in Rernsen
Hall on the subect, "Evidence for
the Existence of Bound Water."

TWO OPEN LETTERS

eNews-Letter Will Be
Issued Once A Week
Following the appearance of this
issue, the NEWS-LETTER Will be
published only once every week,
instead of twice, as formerly, in
accordance with a new policy recently decided upon by the Board
of Control.
The board found this action
necessary after a number of national advertisers left the college
advertising field. The lower revenue that resulted from the withdrawal of these ads, has made
this measure of economy necessary.
The NEWS-LETTER Will appecr
every Wednesday hereafter.

A. S. U. FORMED BY
NAT'L CONVENTION
AT COLUMBUS, OHIO
Students From 113 Schools
Send Delegates To Meetings On Dec. 28-29
UNITED MOVEMENT
Strives For Betterment Of
Economic Position Of
Students In School
With 427 delegates representingstudents in every section of the country, the American Student Union was
formed at a convention held in the
Y. W. C. A. at Columbus, Ohio, on
December 28 and 29. In spite of a
heavy snowstorm, 113 schools sent
representatives-76 colleges and universities and 37 high schools.
This new organization—the American Student Union—is a broad
united student movement against war
and Fascism. Its program states
that it strives for the betterment of
the economic position of students in
school and their right to a job when
graduated. It fights against racial,
religious, and political discrimination
and defends academic freedom. Its
main point stresses the students'
fight against war and supports the
Jxforcl Pledge.
N. S. L., S. L. I. D. Represented
One hundred and forty-one delegates were representatives from N.
S. L. chapters, 116 were members
of the Student League for Industrial
Democracy, while the remainder
were students unaffiliated with these
two organizations, Among the latter
were delegates from twenty college
student councils, many school newspapers, and clubs composed of R. 0.
T. C. officers.
Preceding the American Stundent
Union convention, the Student League
for Industrial Democracy and the
National Student League held their
national conventions and both agreed
to affiliate with the American Student Union.

Amalgamated Clothing Workers of

Bishdied last week at her home,

The fund, in memory of Joseph

kept in trust and the income used for
the assistance of any poor students
If the University ever establishes a
department of architetture, the
money is to be used for students in
that department.

It is a statistical fact that for the
first two month of the first semester the attendance is practically 100
per cent, but then the students realize that there is no penalty attached
to their absence, and from that time
on they fail to attend. This attitude
spreads among other students and in
no time the assembly room is practically empty. The speaker, at such
a time, feels a bit chagrined at the
small audience to which he is addressing his remarks after he has
gone to considerable trouble to prepare an interesting oration for the
benefit of the student body. Therefore, we have reverted to the plan
of compulsory attendance, as was
originally intended, except for the fact
that it is going to be enforced.
The assemblies will henceforth be
conducted in the following manner,
and each student, freshman and sophmore, will abide by the following
regulations:
(1) Each freshman and sophomore
will receive upon entering the assembly room a printed card.
On this
card will be space for the signature
of the student receiving the card, and
in this space he will legibly write his
signature.
(2) The card will be preserved by
the student until the assembly has
been completed, at which time the
student will hand the signed card
to a member of the Student Council
as he passes from the assembly room.
A signed card will not be accepted

at 8.30 p. m. in Latrobe, under the

Fagin, in his first lecture in Baltimore. Following his address, a new
one-act play by Mr. Anderson called
"Mother will be presented. "Mother" has been directed by Dr. Fagin
and the cast includes Mary Alvey,
Jennie Hoffman, S. Vannort Chapman, and Kenneth Silver.

C. Bernard Lewis, Jr., engaged in
his first year in graduate work at
the Johns Hopkins University in the
department of biology, where he is
an instructor, has been selected as
a Rhodes scholar from the New England district. Mr. Lewis, a graduate
of Brown University, was one of four
Rhode Island students to, receive the
honor.
At Brown, Mr. Lewis held positions as captain of the track team,
chairman of the junior prom committee, member of the Caniarian
Club (Student Council), vice-president of the Varsity "B" Club, member Owl and Ring, senior honorary
society, which is composed of outstanding juniors; recipient of the
Francis Wyland scholarship in his
last two years, and member of Sigma
Xi, national honorary scientific organization. On his graduation in 1935,
he received an award for his outstanding record in athletics and
scholarship and character.

been especially in the theatre and
several of his works have been dramatized. His "Wynesburg, Ohio" was

DR. GILBERT CHINARD

BEGIN LECTURES ON
THE UNITED STATES
IN WORLD ECONOMY
Lectures Beginnings Jan. 13
Will Be Held Every
Monday
DR. HART IN CHARGE
Lecture To Continue Until
Close Of School In
June
"The United States in World Economy" will be the subject of a new
lecture series starting Monday, January 13. The course, in charge of
Dr. James Hart, associate professor
of Political Science, will be adminiistered by Mr. Wallace McClure.
The lectures will be held every Monday from 8 p. m. to 9 p. m. The
opportunity for graduate students,
undergraduate
majors in social
sciences, and faculty members to
attend these classes was made possib'e through the efforts of Mr. Theodore Maiturg.
The first of the series, which will
continue until the close of school in
June, will be an introduction, and
the remainder of the course will be
divided into three parts.
Hart Makes Statement
According to Dr. Hart's statement,
"The first half of the course will be
devoted to a study of governmental
machinery in the United States as
an instrument of Democracy. Especial
attention will be given to the treatymaking power under the Constitution. Past use and future possibilities
of the Congressional joint resolution as an alternative to the consent
of two—thirds of the Senate for the
authorization of international acts
will be fully discussed from the standpoint of legality and practicability."
"The second group of lectures will
be devoted to a discussion and comparison of expansive and restrictive
ecoLomic policies and their effects
upon the welfare of the masses in
the United States. Especial attention will be given to the policies of
the present administration particularly to the development of the trade
agreements program authorized by
Act of 1934.
"The burden of the discussion in
the closing lectures will be the economic aspects of the 'Collective System'. Especial attention will be devoted to the economic work of the
League of Nations, to economic
sanctions, and to the necessity of assuring to all people equal opportunity for trade and for the exercise of
their creative energies.

Library Dupliciltes Are On
Sale In Reading Room
Attention has been called to the
fact that duplicates are on sale in
the Main Library in Gilman Hall. Dr.
French, head librarian, says that they
sell at prices second-hand stores offer for books.
Last year $30 was cleared from
sales of these various types of reading.

A. S. U. MEETING
A meeting to form a local organization of the American Student Union will be held today at
1 o'clock in Levering Hall. All
students are invited to attend.

Dr. Gilbert Chinard of the French
department of the Johns Hopkins
University, well known as author,
translator, and editor, spoke yesterday at the assembly on the topic
"International Prejudices and Misunderstandings".
In the opening words of his address, Dr. Chinard mentioned the
fact that in his 15 years of connection with this university this was his
first talk before the student assembly.
Dr. Chinard spoke at first about
racial unity. The common misconception that such a thing exists is
extremely harmful. The people are
"mislead to believe in it by the historian, the politician, and the philosopher or patriot", he asserted.
Racial unity is a myth. It is absolutely non-existent. It is a common
mistake for people of different races
to attribute as characteristics of people of different races all the vices,
while they themselves claim the virtues.
Speaks Of Characteristics
National characteristics was the
next topic on which Dr. Chinard
spoke. He mentioned the fact that
peopile travel for a few weeks in
some other country and base their
idea of the characteristics of the people of that country upon superficialities which they have come in contact with.
When they depart for
their own land, they are convinced
of their own superiority.
"However," Dr. Chinard pointed
out, all these national characteristics
thus discovered are on the surface.
A foriegner who remains in a country for a longer while finds that they
disappear. In their stead they find
the ordinary characteristics of human beings."
To prove his point, Dr. Chinard
told a story of wartime France. The
French had German captives and had
no way of taking care of them. Taking a census of the prisoners, they
found all who had been farmers in
their native land. These were transferred to various farms throughout
France where the men of the house
had gone to war. Surprisingly
enough, these germans got on very
well with their hosts, none of the
national hatreds cropping out in
their daily relations because the
the Germans were on common
ground. As farmers together they
lived in peace and harmony.

CALIFORNIA CHEMIST
JOINS J.H.U. FACULTY
Dr. Robert Dudley Fowler
Is Famous Through His
Splitting Atoms
Dr. Robert Dudley Fowler, 30-year
old chemist from the University of
California, arrived in Baltimore this
week to join the chemistry faculty
of the Johns Hopkins University. He
met two men here who had been
schoolmates of his at the University
of California in 1924, Dr. Donald H
Andrews, professor of chemistry at
the Hopkins, and Dr. J. E. Mayer,
associate professor of chemistry. It
is through Dr. Fowler's achievements
in splitting atoms, which brought him
fame recently in the academic world
that he was appointed to the Hop.
kins faculty. With Dr. G. E. Gibson
as co-worker he developed an eeo.
nomical method of shattering atoms
Dr. Fowler's chief interest lies in
the field of the neutron, and his
method of atom breaking is chiefly
useful in isolating neutrons.

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 10, 1936

Jay Walks
By DAVID CAPLAN

Basketball To
Make Bow Tonight
The Hopkins basketball team
makes its current bow in the Maryland Intercollegiate squad at Homewood gym.
Both teams have a goodly number
of veterans returning from last year,
and the game promises to be a fast,
exciting contest with Washington
slightly favored because of their
better showing last year. Up to date,
the Jays have won one game while
losing two, defeating an alumni team
and going down to defeat against
strong Temple and Army quintets.
These latter teams, however, boast
two of the best squads in the East
and defeats by them are no insult to
any school, particularly when it is
considered that the Jays gave a very
respectable performance in each instance.
The
Maryland
Intercollegiate
League can look forward to a closefought and interesting season this
year. The league is very evenly balanced with no really outstanding
team, although Washington and St.
Mary's are the pre-season favorites.
With the possible exception of Western Maryland, all the members
should be stronger than last year,
with the Jays right up among the
leaders.
The Hopkinsites will present a veteran line-up, only one member of
the starting team being a newcomer,
Melvin, a former prep star at
Friends School. Capt. George Margolis and Carl Rasin will start at the
guard positions, with Melvin playing center, while the forward posts
will be taken care of by Herb Siegal
and Les "Boyles" Margolis. Siegal is
one of the outstanding forwards in
the State while Capt. Margolis is expected to prove a bulwark on defense.

Gym boree
Merits Praise
It is appropriate at this time to
cast a vote of thanks to the athletic
department, 0. D. K., and all those
connected with the gymboree for the
splendid success which this benefit
show met with. More than five hundred persons were present at what
proved to be a very interesting and
varied program. According to latest
reports, one hundred and fifty-five
dollars have already been taken in
and still more remains to be collected.
The success of the gymboree reflects brightly on the entire student
body as a whole, for it occurred just
at a time when the school spirit of
the Hopkins, or rather lack of school
spirit, was being bemoaned from all
sides. It is as least a proof that
such spirit at the Hopkins is not, as
many were beginning to suppose,
non-existent, and, with a potentially
strong basketball team in the offing
there should be no lack of supporters..

NAMED TRUSTEE
Dr. Lewis H. Weed, Baltimore, a
member of the faculty of the Johns
Hopkins Medical School, has been
elected to the board of trustees of
the Carnegie Institute of Washington, which has recently authorized
an appropriation of $572,000 for scientific work in 1936.

Gartner To Speak Here
Dr. Ross A. Gartner, of the
chemistry faculty of the University of Minnesota and as resident
lecturer at Cornell University during 1935, will deliver the third in
the Dohme lecture series this afternoon at four o'clock in Rernsen
Hall on the subect, "Evidence for
the Existence of Bound Water."

TWO OPEN LETTERS

eNews-Letter Will Be
Issued Once A Week
Following the appearance of this
issue, the NEWS-LETTER Will be
published only once every week,
instead of twice, as formerly, in
accordance with a new policy recently decided upon by the Board
of Control.
The board found this action
necessary after a number of national advertisers left the college
advertising field. The lower revenue that resulted from the withdrawal of these ads, has made
this measure of economy necessary.
The NEWS-LETTER Will appecr
every Wednesday hereafter.

A. S. U. FORMED BY
NAT'L CONVENTION
AT COLUMBUS, OHIO
Students From 113 Schools
Send Delegates To Meetings On Dec. 28-29
UNITED MOVEMENT
Strives For Betterment Of
Economic Position Of
Students In School
With 427 delegates representingstudents in every section of the country, the American Student Union was
formed at a convention held in the
Y. W. C. A. at Columbus, Ohio, on
December 28 and 29. In spite of a
heavy snowstorm, 113 schools sent
representatives-76 colleges and universities and 37 high schools.
This new organization—the American Student Union—is a broad
united student movement against war
and Fascism. Its program states
that it strives for the betterment of
the economic position of students in

It is a statistical fact that for the
first two month of the first semester the attendance is practically 100
per cent, but then the students realize that there is no penalty attached
to their absence, and from that time
on they fail to attend. This attitude
spreads among other students and in
no time the assembly room is practically empty. The speaker, at such
a time, feels a bit chagrined at the
small audience to which he is addressing his remarks after he has
gone to considerable trouble to prepare an interesting oration for the
benefit of the student body. Therefore, we have reverted to the plan
of compulsory attendance, as was
originally intended, except for the fact
that it is going to be enforced.
The assemblies will henceforth be
conducted in the following manner,
and each student, freshman and sophmore, will abide by the following
regulations:
(1) Each freshman and sophomore
will receive upon entering the assembly room a printed card.
On this
card will be space for the signature
of the student receiving the card, and
in this space he will legibly write his
signature.
(2) The card will be preserved by
the student until the assembly has
been completed, at which time the
student will hand the signed card
to a member of the Student Council
as he passes from the assembly room.
A signed card will not be accepted

DR. GILBERT CHINARD

BEGIN LECTURES ON
THE UNITED STATES
IN WORLD ECONOMY
Lectures Beginnings Jan. 13
Will Be Held Every
Monday
DR. HART IN CHARGE
Lecture To Continue Until
Close Of School In
June
"The United States in World Economy" will be the subject of a new
lecture series starting Monday, January 13. The course, in charge of
Dr. James Hart, associate professor
of Political Science, will be adminiistered by Mr. Wallace McClure.
The lectures will be held every Monday from 8 p. m. to 9 p. m. The
opportunity for graduate students,
undergraduate
majors in social
sciences, and faculty members to
attend these classes was made possib'e through the efforts of Mr. Theodore Maiturg.
The first of the series, which will
continue until the close of school in
June, will be an introduction, and
the remainder of the course will be
divided into three parts.
Hart Makes Statement
According to Dr. Hart's statement,
"The first half of the course will be
devoted to a study of governmental
machinery in the United States as
an instrument of Democracy. Especial
attention will be given to the treatymaking power under the Constitution. Past use and future possibilities
of the Congressional joint resolution as an alternative to the consent
of two—thirds of the Senate for the
authorization of international acts
will be fully discussed from the standpoint of legality and practicability."
"The second group of lectures will
be devoted to a discussion and comparison of expansive and restrictive
ecoLomic policies and their effects
upon the welfare of the masses in
the United States. Especial attention will be given to the policies of
the present administration particularly to the development of the trade
agreements program authorized by
Act of 1934.
"The burden of the discussion in
the closing lectures will be the economic aspects of the 'Collective System'. Especial attention will be devoted to the economic work of the
League of Nations, to economic
sanctions, and to the necessity of assuring to all people equal opportunity for trade and for the exercise of
their creative energies.

A. S. U. MEETING
A meeting to form a local organization of the American Student Union will be held today at
1 o'clock in Levering Hall. All
students are invited to attend.

Dr. Gilbert Chinard of the French
department of the Johns Hopkins
University, well known as author,
translator, and editor, spoke yesterday at the assembly on the topic
"International Prejudices and Misunderstandings".
In the opening words of his address, Dr. Chinard mentioned the
fact that in his 15 years of connection with this university this was his
first talk before the student assembly.
Dr. Chinard spoke at first about
racial unity. The common misconception that such a thing exists is
extremely harmful. The people are
"mislead to believe in it by the historian, the politician, and the philosopher or patriot", he asserted.
Racial unity is a myth. It is absolutely non-existent. It is a common
mistake for people of different races
to attribute as characteristics of people of different races all the vices,
while they themselves claim the virtues.
Speaks Of Characteristics
National characteristics was the
next topic on which Dr. Chinard
spoke. He mentioned the fact that
peopile travel for a few weeks in
some other country and base their
idea of the characteristics of the people of that country upon superficialities which they have come in contact with.
When they depart for
their own land, they are convinced
of their own superiority.
"However," Dr. Chinard pointed
out, all these national characteristics
thus discovered are on the surface.
A foriegner who remains in a country for a longer while finds that they
disappear. In their stead they find
the ordinary characteristics of human beings."
To prove his point, Dr. Chinard
told a story of wartime France. The
French had German captives and had
no way of taking care of them. Taking a census of the prisoners, they
found all who had been farmers in
their native land. These were transferred to various farms throughout
France where the men of the house
had gone to war. Surprisingly
enough, these germans got on very
well with their hosts, none of the
national hatreds cropping out in
their daily relations because the
the Germans were on common
ground. As farmers together they
lived in peace and harmony.

CALIFORNIA CHEMIST
JOINS J.H.U. FACULTY
Dr. Robert Dudley Fowler
Is Famous Through His
Splitting Atoms
Dr. Robert Dudley Fowler, 30-year
old chemist from the University of
California, arrived in Baltimore this
week to join the chemistry faculty
of the Johns Hopkins University. He
met two men here who had been
schoolmates of his at the University
of California in 1924, Dr. Donald H
Andrews, professor of chemistry at
the Hopkins, and Dr. J. E. Mayer,
associate professor of chemistry. It
is through Dr. Fowler's achievements
in splitting atoms, which brought him
fame recently in the academic world
that he was appointed to the Hop.
kins faculty. With Dr. G. E. Gibson
as co-worker he developed an eeo.
nomical method of shattering atoms
Dr. Fowler's chief interest lies in
the field of the neutron, and his
method of atom breaking is chiefly
useful in isolating neutrons.

HOPKINS QUINTET
OPEN HOME GAME
WITH SHOREMEN
Jays Bow To Army Five
After Tight Skirmish
Last Wednesday
"MONK" MEYER
SCORES FOR CADETS
Margolis, Siegel, And Melvin Star; Jays Play Well
All Through Tilt
(Continued from Page 1, Col. 1)
make the heart grow fonder." "Virgy" Rubing-er, Dimi Traggis, Les
Rosenthal and Hank Mahan round
out the varsity squad.
Washington A Veteran Team
The Shoremen come to town with
a strong veteran squad, sharing preseason predictions with the title
holding Mount St. Mary team. Possessing a big heavy squad, the boys
from Washington College play a
hard brand of ball that should give
Hopkins plenty to worry ar,151it. The
offensive is built about four capable
veterans.
Salters and Horowitz, high scoring forward combination and Wilmot and Huffman.
/Jig Zebrouski
rounds out a probable starting five.
Coach Kibler has a bunch of big boys
who are content to play straight
basketball. Its record is but marred
by a defeat at the hands of the
strong undefeated Long Island U.
quintet.
In the preliminary game the Jayvee classh with the Freshmen squad.
The spirit amongst the teams is
plenty high. Coaches Lotz and Dotterweich, optomistic per usual, refuse to state whom they think will
'emerge the victor.
Rusty from the effects of their prolonged vacation, the Hopkins hoopsters bowed before a superior Army
quintet at West Point last Wednesday 39-24. The future Generals,
opening their season with the contest, presented a line--up studded
with football stars which wore Hopkins down by their gridiron tactics
and forged ahead to a safe lead in
the last period.
Kadets Score Soon
Opening fast, the West Pointers
ran up a lead of 6-0 before the
JohnnieS had found themselves. Ken
Dawalt, Cadet captain and reputed
to be one of the fastest men basketball circles, opened the scoring with
two arching hoops from outside of
the foul line. Monk Meyer, of AllAmerican grid fame, then tossed in
a neat one-hander from the side
lines. Carl Rasin opened the scoring
for Hopkins with a long swishing
heave from mid-court which cut the
net without touching the rim.
The teams continued battling on
fairly even terms till the half, with
the ball in the possession of the Blue
Jays for the majority of the time.
The inability of the Jays to wink
their suckers time and again prevented them from drawing into the

HOME WOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., JANUARY 10, 1936

Jay Walks
By DAVID CAPLAN

Basketball To
Make Bow Tonight
The Hopkins basketball team
makes its current bow in the Maryland Intercollegiate squad at Homewood gym.
Both teams have a goodly number
of veterans returning from last year,
and the game promises to be a fast,
exciting contest with Washington
slightly favored because of their
better showing last year. Up to date,
the Jays have won one game while
losing two, defeating an alumni team
and going down to defeat against
strong Temple and Army quintets.
These latter teams, however, boast
two of the best squads in the East
and defeats by them are no insult to
any school, particularly when it is
considered that the Jays gave a very
respectable performance in each instance.
The
Maryland
Intercollegiate
League can look forward to a closefought and interesting season this
year. The league is very evenly balanced with no really outstanding
team, although Washington and St.
Mary's are the pre-season favorites.
With the possible exception of Western Maryland, all the members
should be stronger than last year,
with the Jays right up among the
leaders.
The Hopkinsites will present a veteran line-up, only one member of
the starting team being a newcomer,
Melvin, a former prep star at
Friends School. Capt. George Margolis and Carl Rasin will start at the
guard positions, with Melvin playing center, while the forward posts
will be taken care of by Herb Siegal
and Les "Boyles" Margolis. Siegal is
one of the outstanding forwards in
the State while Capt. Margolis is expected to prove a bulwark on defense.

Gym boree
Merits Praise
It is appropriate at this time to
cast a vote of thanks to the athletic
department, 0. D. K., and all those
connected with the gymboree for the
splendid success which this benefit
show met with. More than five hundred persons were present at what
proved to be a very interesting and
varied program. According to latest
reports, one hundred and fifty-five
dollars have already been taken in
and still more remains to be collected.
The success of the gymboree reflects brightly on the entire student
body as a whole, for it occurred just
at a time when the school spirit of
the Hopkins, or rather lack of school
spirit, was being bemoaned from all
sides. It is as least a proof that
such spirit at the Hopkins is not, as
many were beginning to suppose,
non-existent, and, with a potentially
strong basketball team in the offing
there should be no lack of supporters..

Intramural Tourney Planned
For those men in school who have
already reached an advanced stage
in boxing, and for those so called
"hard" men an intramural boxing
tournament is planned. The date of
the tournament has been set for February 18, 20 and 21. Entries for this
tournament must be in by February
8. There will be eight weight divisions as follows: 115 lbs., 125 lbs.,
135 lbs., 145 lbs., 155 lbs., 165 lbs.,
175 lbs., and the heavy-weight. Regular collegiate boxing rules will govern the tournament allowing a
weight variation of 4 pounds.
In
other words a man weighing 119 lbs.,
and under will be in the 115 pound
class. Each bout will consist of three
two--minute rounds, and the winner
of the various classes will be awarded minature gold boxing gloves.

made by Reuben Baer yesterday, the
Hopkins varsity swimmers will
make their first big splash this Friday night at 8.00 p. m. against Randolph-Macon College of Ashland, Va.
The meet will take place at Baltimore City College pool, 33rd Street
and the Alameda. In between the
varsity events there will be a meet
between the Hopkins freshmen and
the Baltimore Polytechnic Institute.
Although Randolph-Macon team
has been active in swimming circles
for less than two years, it has a
team which should give Hopkins a
run for its money. Hopkins will enter, however, a slight favorite due
to the inexperience of Randolph-Macon.
The J. H. U. aggregation is fortified by the presence of Bill Hazlett
and John Macgill. These two men
are veterans from last year and are
expected to be of great assistance
this season.
However, Hopkins is very weak in
the diving departments, since both of
last year's men did not return.
The probable line-up:
320 yard freestyle relay — Macgill,
Hill, Noonan an dL. Adler.
200-yard breast stroke—Hazlett and
Moses.
150-yard back stroke — Wiener and
Macgill.
40-yard free style — L. Adler and
Noonan.
80-yard free style — L. Adler and
Hill.
220-yard free style — B. Adler and
Jacobs.
440-yard free style—B. Adler and
Goodman.
Diving—Undecided.
